instruction: What kinds of spectrum were used in collecting the in situ leaf reflectance spectra for developing SDIs-based monitoring models to detect Southern Corn Rust (SCR) and classify its severity levels?
Output: The in situ leaf reflectance spectra were visible and nir spectrum in the wavelength range of 350-2500 nm.

instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were used to develop the SDIs for SCR detection and severity classification based on the collected leaf reflectance spectra?
Output: The RELIEF-F algorithm was used to develop two SDIs for SCR detection (Healthy Index, HI) and severity classification (Severity Index, SI) based on the collected leaf reflectance spectra.

instruction: What metric was chosen to assess the performance in collecting the in situ leaf reflectance spectra for developing SDIs-based monitoring models to detect Southern Corn Rust (SCR) and classify its severity levels, and how much higher were the accuracies compared to the best vegetation indices (VIs)-based model?
Output: The metric chosen to assess the performance of the developed SCR-SDIs was overall accuracy. The developed SCR-SDIs achieved an overall accuracy of 87% in SCR detection and 70% in severity classification. These accuracies were 1.1% and 8.3% higher, respectively, compared to the best vegetation indices (VIs)-based model under study.

instruction: How did the researchers compare the performance of the developed SDIs with the stress-related vegetation indices (VIs) for Southern Corn Rust (SCR) detection and severity classification?
Output: The researchers compared the performance of the developed SDIs with the stress-related vegetation indices (VIs) by employing a support vector machine (SVM). They assessed and compared the performances of the SDIs-based models with 38 stress-related VIs identified in the literature. The evaluation was based on the overall accuracy achieved by each model in SCR detection and severity classification. The SDIs-based models developed in the related study achieved an overall accuracy of 87% and 70% in SCR detection and severity classification, respectively. These accuracies were 1.1% and 8.3% higher than the other best VIs-based model under the related study.

instruction: Can the developed spectral disease indices (SDIs) be used for the fast and nondestructive diagnosis of Southern Corn Rust (SCR) in the field, as intended in the related study?
Output: Yes, the developed spectral disease indices (SDIs) can be used for the fast and nondestructive diagnosis of Southern Corn Rust (SCR) in the field, as intended in the related study. The related study developed SDIs-based monitoring models that can detect SCR-infected leaves and classify SCR damage severity. These models achieved an overall accuracy of 87% and 70% in SCR detection and severity classification, respectively, which were higher than the other best vegetation indices-based model under the related study. Therefore, the SDIs-based models are considered a promising tool for the fast and nondestructive diagnosis of SCR in the field over large areas.
